section.title: A quick reference of &odis; Operation
section.simpara: In this section, we'll try to give a quick and brief rundown of the operation of &odis;

section.title: Using the command file
section.para: A command file (specified by the "-c" option) is practically mandatory for useful disassembly. The command file is explained in more detail in . Briefly, the command file can be used for three things.

listitem.formalpara: Specify commandline options to pass to &odis;.During the process of disassembling a program, you will undoubtedly have to run the disassembly several times. To avoid the necessity of having to pass the options to &odis; each time, the commanline options (see for a desctiption of the options) by beginning the line with "+".

Specify Data boundariesYou can specify sections of code as being data instead of code. This cause &odis; to not attempt to disassemble these areas as code, but rather as either ASCII data, or constants. These constants can be specified as either numeric data, either hexadecimal or decimal, or as labels. This is explained further in .
Specify an alternate label class You can specify that the label reference for a line or range of lines is different than the default. This is a rather complex concept and is explained more fully in

Specify Comments to insert into source code You can specify comments to be placed into the source listing and source file. Comments can be beneficial to you during disassembly and also for later reference. As you come up with comments, you can add them as needed. See for details.

section.title: Data (noncode) Areas
section.para: Some sections of the module will not be code. There may be strings of text, or constants, which may be lookup tables or or other constants of any sort. To specify a Data area, the command is preceded by a letter corresponding to the type of data. Please see for a fuller explanation.

section.title: Addressing Mode Specification

note.para: For a full description of Label Class please refer to

section.para: When disassembling code, &odis; will determine a reference in the operand to be a certain type based upon the mode of the assembler command. &odis; has a default label class to assign a certain addressing mode, depending upon the target system. For code in a program module, for example, &odis; will assume that, since register U usually points to the base of the data area, that something indexed by U refers to data, and will assign it class "D" (the default class for Data).
